Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Multiscale modeling of the mechanical behavior and deformation mechanisms in small scale metallic structure exhibiting epitaxial interfaces

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tuskegee University's Research Initiation Award entitled - Multiscale Modeling of the Mechanical Behavior and Deformation Mechanisms in Small Scale Metallic Structure Exhibiting Epitaxial Interfaces - has the goal to initiate a research program in multiscale modeling of the mechanical behavior of small scale metallic structures, with a focus on the treatment of interfaces and boundaries. Interfaces play a critical role in governing the mechanical behavior of structures at those length scales. However, a complete understanding of the underlying physical mechanisms is missing due to their complexity and dependence on all length scales: atomic, defect, and microstructure. To this end, the project initiates computational materials research at two scales: nanoscale, using molecular dynamics, and mesoscale, using crystal plasticity. The work will create and validate physically informed micro and mesoscale computational models for interfaces. The research objectives are to create and validate a dislocation dynamics (DD) framework which accounts for the interaction of interfaces with dislocations in epitaxial heterogeneous structures, including dislocation absorption, transmission, nucleation, and core spreading; and to use the "interface-enhanced" DD framework to perform carefully controlled virtual experiments to evaluate the ability of the viscoplastic self-consistent polycrystalline plasticity model to account for the same type of interfaces addressed in this research. To help accomplish these objectives, a collaboration with the experienced multiscale modeling team at the Center of Advanced Vehicular Systems at Mississippi State University has been forged with a long-term relationship in mind.

The project will lead to establishing a computational mechanics program, providing synergistic research activities to undergraduate students, and infusing modeling and simulation into the mechanical engineering curriculum at Tuskegee University. The project will also document the mentoring practices and collect data to set the stage for future research on broadening the participation of minority students through intensive research in engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supported by the Division of Human Resource Development/ Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program, this project aimed at initiating research in the area of modeling the mechanical behavior and interface structure of heterogeneous metallic laminates at the nanoscale. A major finding of this research is that the defect structure of the interface joining two metals of the same unit cell structure, here that referred to as face centered cubic, FCC, can take different morphology from the one conventionally accepted by theory and experiment. This new structure, which occurs under high tensile stress normal to the interface or at high temperature, was observed in atomistics simulations of interfaces between Cu and Ni in nanoscale laminates. This structure contains dislocations (line defects) which are not energetically favorable raising an interesting question about the reason for its occurrence. The occurrence of this structure was analyzed and rationalized in terms of the nonlinear part of the dislocation energy, the core energy. It was shown that under high stress there is a cross over point when the dislocation with the lower core energy becomes the one with the higher energy, providing the explanation for the observed phenomenon. Equally important, the project aimed at involving undergraduate minority students in this type of research and to introduce the general field of computational mechanics into the curriculum of mechanical engineering. To this end, ten undergraduate students where trained and monitored, five of home produced undergraduate theses, and a number of step-by-step modules for performing basic calculations in atomistics shared on a Wiki type cyberinfrastructure hosted by Mississippi State University.


Last Modified: 01/30/2017
Modified by: Firas Akasheh

A major finding of this research is that the defect structure of the interface joining two metals of the same unit cell structure, here that referred to as face centered cubic, FCC, can take different morphology from the one conventionally accepted by theory and experiment. Equally important, the project aimed at involving undergraduate minority students in this type of research and to introduce the general field of computational mechanics into the curriculum of mechanical engineering. To this end, ten undergraduate students where trained and monitored, five of home produced undergraduate theses, and a number of step-by-step modules for performing basic calculations in atomistics shared on a Wiki type cyberinfrastructure hosted by Mississippi State University.
